LEGAL AID AND ADVICE ORDINANCE, 1956


    1. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Chief Minister what steps, if any, are being taken to bring the Legal Aid and Advice Ordinance, 1956, into operation; which portions thereof it is intended to bring into operation first, and when.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, discussions were held with representatives of the Bar Committee towards the end of August with a view to clearing away difficulties which might prevent the Bar Committee recommending the profession to give its support to the measure. Since then, other and more urgent matters have been occupying my attention. I hope, however, that further progress

Column: 632

will be made in this matter in the near future. In the meanwhile, I am unable to give the hon. Member the other information which he seeks.

    Mr Marshall: Sir, I would ask the Chief Minister what prevents the establishment now of the Department for Legal Aid and Advice? It takes time to appoint officials and to have an organisation. Why do we not start now?

    The Chief Minister: Sir, it is felt that before we start organising the Department, the co-operation of the Bar Committee should be assured to this Government.

SINGAPORE RIOTS
(Arrests)


    2. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Chief Secretary to give the number of arrests between 25th October and 31st October, 1956:

    (a) for rioting;

    (b) for breaking curfew;

    (c) under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance;

    (d) for other offences.

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: (a) 290 persons were arrested for rioting;

    (b) 962 for breaking curfew;

    (c) 912 under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance;

    (d) 55 for other offences not necessarily connected with the riots.

    3. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Chief Secretary to give the number of such alleged curfew breakers who were detained without bail for more than 24 hours.

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: Returns from the various police divisions indicate that 258 alleged curfew breakers were detained without bail for more than 24 hours.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC SECURITY ORDINANCE
(Number of persons detained)


    4. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Chief Secretary to give the number of

persons arrested under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance within the aforementioned period who were detained -

    (a) for 24 hours or less;

    (b) for 48 hours or less;

    (c) for less than 16 days;

and the number of persons against whom Detention Orders have been made by the Governor in Council between 1st October and 18th November, 1956.

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: Of the persons arrested under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance -

    (a) 320 were detained for 24 hours or less;

    (b) 2 were detained for more than 24 hours but not more than 48;

    (c) 184 were detained for more than 48 hours but less than 16 days.

    Between 1st October and 18th November, Detention Orders have been made in respect of 216 persons.

    Mr Marshall: Do I understand, Sir, that in the circumstances there are 194 still under detention whose cases are being considered?

    Mr Goode: No, Sir. The procedure under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance is that unless a Detention Order is made before the expiry of the time during which the police may detain a person, he must be released.

    Mr Marshall: Sir, but I understand that 912 were arrested under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance. Of these, 502 have been released. That leaves us 410 not released. Of these, Detention Orders have been made against 216. That leaves us 194 unaccounted for.

    Mr Goode: The question, I take it, Sir, is: Will I please account for them? I will try and do that, Sir. It is quite true that there are a number who are not covered by the answers I gave to the question originally put to me. The explanation of that is this, Sir, that a number of persons who were originally arrested by the police under their powers conferred by section 17 (b) of

Column: 634

the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance were later found to have been concerned with incidents such as curfew breaking and rioting and even arson, and they have therefore been charged under the ordinary laws of the colony. The explanation is that a number of persons who were held originally under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance are now being charged in the ordinary way for criminal offences.

    Mr Marshall: One more question, Sir. Of these 194, how many are, in fact, now detained under the Banishment Ordinance?

    Mr Goode: The hon. Member is quite right, Sir. I did omit to say that there are a comparatively few who are now held under banishment procedure. I have not the figures available, but I think it is about 30.

    Mr Marshall: Thank you.

    With regard to contributions to Commonwealth defence, the Contribution to Imperial Defence Ordinance (Chapter 64 of the Revised Edition) prescribes that an annual contribution of $4 million will be made to imperial defence from the funds of the Colony of the Straits Settlements. APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order read for resumption of debate on motion-[7th November, 1956]:

    Question again proposed, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

10.15 a.m.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, it seems to me that it is usual for the Financial Secretary year in and year out to tell us that we must be taxed more and that the future is bleak. In fact, such a warning was given by the Financial Secretary in the Official Report, Vol. 1, No. 19, dated 21st November, 1955, at col. 1063 where he said that he was not going to be accused of crying wolf once more and that we were going to be faced "with the hard reality of actual deficits". Now we are coming to the end of 1956 and we know the exact position, and the position is that we still have a surplus. Invariably there is always a surplus in the matter of collection of taxes. This fact is known by everybody almost every year and in effect the Financial Secretary admits it. On page 1 of his Budget speech he says:

    "In all, it seems likely that revenue collections will amount to about $217 million compared with the estimate of $215 million."

    Here again, Sir, the Financial Secretary admits that the estimate for tax collection is always low, whereas the estimate for expenditure will always be higher than it should be. Why is it so? I think it is just to create the impression that additional taxation is necessary.

    On page 2 of his Budget speech in the second paragraph, he says:

    "...that the working for 1956 will show a small surplus, possibly of the order of $2 or $3 million."

    This is an admission by the Financial Secretary himself, Sir, and it is important.

    Again on page 5, in the fourth paragraph, he says:

Column: 638



    "...actual expenditure has in the past in variably fallen short of the estimate. It is likely that this will occur again in 1957."

    And again on page 6 the same tune is played, and here he says:

    "...it is possible that actual expenditure will fall considerably short of the estimate."

    Sir, in his Budget speech the Financial Secretary has drawn our attention to the fact that expenditure will not be as high as has been put forward in the Estimates. It is significant that he has drawn our attention to it more than once and, because he is supposed to be an expert on the subject, we must believe that expenditure will definitely fall short of the estimate as presented by the Government. Now here we have a case where every year you are going to have the collection of revenue more than the actual expenditure which, according to the estimate put out, will be less than what is presented to us, and in the end there will always be a surplus. This has been going on through the years. Every year we have had this state of affairs, and this leads us to ask the question whether there is any necessity at all for further taxation.

    I think, Sir, with all the warnings by the Financial Secretary that the future is bleak, we must tighten our belts, we must pay more, expenditure is mounting and all that, all this tends to give the impression to hon. Members in this House as well as to the public at large that we are in real need of further taxation when, in fact, from all that has been said, there is no necessity at all. Perhaps it is just the way with everybody, just like boys between the ages of 8 and 10, that it is a habit to hoard some money. It is just an instinct with Government, I think, to want to feel the money in its pocket and jingle it and say, "Now, I have the money and if I want to spend it on anything extravagant, I can do it. There is no need to cut my coat according to the cloth. There is no need to think of saving on this little item or that. The public will pay whenever we tax them, because the power is in our hands. So long as we have money, well, it is public money, although we may have contributed a little to it in the way of income tax. So let us spend it, let us be generous

Column: 639

with it." If that is the case, Sir, I think it is absolutely wrong. We are here as guardians of the people's money. We have to spend it wisely. We must think of every cent that has to be spent. It is because it is other people's money, the public's money, that we should exercise even more care in spending it or even in wanting it. I cite you one case, Sir. The Government promised us something last year during the debate on the Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill, but I am still looking forward to that promise being kept. I refer hon. Members to the same Official Report that I have just quoted from, this time at col. 1010, where the Chief Minister (he is now the Member for Cairnhill), in reply to a question by my hon. Friend the Member for Tiong Bahru on the question of the personal emoluments of the civil service, said:

    "I am far from complacent about the expenditures of the Government. We have been seven months in office, Sir, and this sort of axing is not done in a day. I certainly intend to pursue methods which I have in mind for greater reduction in expenditure in the future."

    Here, Sir, was a promise by the then Chief Minister to look into the matter of the expenditures of the Government. Today, Sir, we still have, with the exception of one Member, the same people sitting on the Government Front Benches, and I expect that, because it is a Labour Front Coalition Government, it will carry out the same promises that it has made to the people, and I hope that regarding this matter it will carry out its promise. According to the Budget, however, I think the increase is in the region of $98 million to $113 million. That is a big jump for personal emoluments. I think the Government in this matter did try and tell the public, "We will try our best and streamline the Government. We have, in fact, an Organisation Committee to streamline everything, to advise us on methods, to advise us on ways and means of giving a more efficient service to the public and at a lesser cost." Yet, with all these methods and streamlining experts, nothing substantial has been produced. In fact, if we draw a graph on a matter of expenditure of this nature, we will find that it goes on

Column: 640

-I will say Y is equal to MX plus C, which is a straight line graph, showing that it is going up all the time. Nothing more.

    Now let us consider again whether Government actually needs all this extra money by taxation for next year's Budget. During the Second Reading we heard from the Financial Secretary that the relief for income tax will be lowered from $3,000 to $2,500 for a single individual, and that this is a "must". Sir, I have received news again through the Press that the Government has waived that reduction and has restored the floor for income tax to $3,000. This is really commendable - that the Government can still take heed of public opinion. I do not quarrel with granting relief to people paying income tax, but one thing which strikes me is this. Here you have a government telling the people that we need more money. We must raise our money by income tax and by more tax. We must raise money by taxing cigarettes, by taxing on other vices like sweepstakes and so on. We must have direct taxation. We must have indirect taxation. All these are "musts". And after the Government has said that all these are "musts", we find that suddenly, because there is pressure from outside, it is going to be unpopular, people are going to throw mud at the Government more than is necessary, the Government says, "Oh no, we are going to replace that $500 tax relief. No, we do not need that much money from taxation of that kind. We can make up for that. We can still spend our money and not feel the shortage." Let me put the case this way. If the Government needs money and collects it by that sort of taxation, and then it withdraws the proposal to impose that kind of taxation, then I believe that every time it wants to impose a tax on something and enough opposition is whipped up against it, I am sure the Government will in a similar way withdraw and say, "We will withdraw the taxation - ".

    Mr D. S. Marshall (Cairnhill): We are democrats and not dictators.

Column: 641



    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Exactly, exactly! So we have this sort of affair going on every time. The Government says it is going to tax something and that it is a "must", but when it comes up against opposition, it withdraws. So its "musts" are actually elastic ones and not like an unbending metal rod. You cannot twist it, nor can you bend it. In fact, I think there is no necessity whatsoever for any taxation. There is no need for increased taxation. You can spend the amount of money derived from the old tax and that will be more than sufficient.

    Now let us look at the proposed taxation programme of the Government. The first item on the list is income tax. I would like to draw the attention of the Government to its old election pledge - that it will only tax those who are most able to bear the burden. It is a very good idea but the point is how to carry it out in practice. Theory is one thing, practice is another. If you say one thing is good and then you do not practise it, then what will people think about you? Not much, I am afraid!

    Mr Marshall: He is talking!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: I am talking! In the matter of taxation there are two ways. One is direct taxation, by way of income tax. The other is indirect taxation. If we have direct taxation, and income tax, then we really put the burden on those who can best bear it, because in income tax those who earn more will pay more and those who earn less will pay less. I think that is the fairest way of taxation. In the matter of indirect taxation, you find so many people in the streets - whether they are rich or poor - indulge in their little vices and their bad habits with no distinction, and, in fact, many of the rich do not. So, if any money is to be drawn from the public, the rich man will pay his little share, probably in the ratio of one in half a million. I am talking of adults. I do not know, but it may extend to young people, and that will even make the share of a rich man less. On this type of taxation you tax not only on the bad habits of the people, such as smoking, gambling and drinking, but I

Column: 642

am afraid that it will also touch on the daily necessities of everybody. I will come to that soon enough. So if the Government is going to carry out its policy and say that tax is going to be imposed on those who can best afford it, it must not have direct taxation and then indirect taxation. Indirect taxation must be reduced to the absolute minimum.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): No schools, no teachers!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Do not worry about that. We will have plenty of them! It is only a matter of how you spend your money.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Manufacture it!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: There is no need to manufacture anything of that sort. On a matter like this, it is just like a firm engaging a manager. The manager will say, "We will spend this and we will spend that and we will gather our income this way and that way." But if at the end of the financial year it is found that the manager is not going to make his ends meet, not only will the shop have to close down but the manager himself will get the sack. He will be very glad to supplement the tax programme of the Labour Front Coalition Government if he gets unemployed! Let us come back to the first item of taxation - income tax. The Government is now proposing to do away with the lowering of that $500 relief, but it still intends to do away with the three per cent and the four per cent and change these rates to five per cent. Sir, in this connection the Financial Secretary stated that a programme like this would bring in an income of roughly $1.5 million. This is a small sum, but if the Government takes away that $500, as it intends to do, and only changes the rates of three per cent and four per cent to five per cent, then the only people who will be affected will be the present income taxpayers - only 19,000 persons. It can easily be calculated that each person is going to pay the Government roughly -

Column: 643



    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): $15 on chargeable income.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: $15 extra. So $15 multiplied by 19,000 comes up to a very negligible sum.

    Mr Marshall: Quarter of a million dollars.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Good for one trip to Kuala Lumpur or Hongkong or a trip to England to observe transport! Sir, it is my firm conviction that such a revision of taxation, which brings in no visible increase, no substantial increase, should be dropped immediately. In fact, the people who are being taxed now - the 19,000 people - are paying quite a large percentage of the revenue of the country.

    Mr Marshall: Not true.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: What we need is a more efficient Income Tax Department to bring in those who have not yet been taxed but are within that taxable range. As far as income tax is concerned, Sir, I know that we only grant relief to the income taxpayer, his wife and his children. Let us remember that we are living in the East and in the East the set-up of the family is entirely different from that in the West. In the East the parents are considered as an integral part of the family, in fact, the most important part of the family. When the children grow up and after they have obtained their education and are able to earn their living, they will, by custom and tradition, support their parents. In fact, it is their duty to do so. This, Sir, is one of the best attributes of those who live in the East. The family ties are strong. So we have here the case of the taxpayer supporting his parents, instead of the father running along to the Social Welfare Department and saying, "Sir, I have no job and my son is not supporting me. I must live on the public dole." The public dole is $15 per person. If you calculate the number of old parents who depend on the dole, you will find that the money given out comes up to a very sizeable sum. That sum of money should have come from Government, but

Column: 644

it is saved for the Government. Why is this expenditure saved? Because of this Chinese tradition, that the son who is able to earn a living should support his parents.

    We in this House, Sir, have declared ourselves to be staunch supporters of the cultures of the East. We have said that we support Chinese culture, Indian culture and so on, but we must prove that we are really supporting it by implementing measures which will convince the public at large that we recognise that fact and that we will do it. The Government has had troubles with the Chinese school students who said, "You are destroying Chinese culture", and they told the Chief Minister, "Chinese culture says that we must hsueh hsi" and the Minister for Education said, "You must respect the teachers and honour your parents." Here, then, is the opportunity for the Government to ram home the fact to the people of Singapore that it is going to uphold Chinese culture and it is going to amend its laws in accordance with the way of life of the people in the East. If you are talking about the West, then you may object to my talking about people in the East. But let us also talk about England. Let us talk about America. These are countries that the Government likes. In America and in England you still have relief for parents, and if you look it up, you will find that in special cases they give allowances to such people. So why cannot we in Singapore do that? If we do that faster and quicker, it will be better for us. [Interruption.]

    Regarding the 3 per cent and 4 per cent rates of taxation again, Sir, it is contrary to the principles of the Labour Front. The burden of taxation will not be on those who are more able to bear it, but it will be on everybody who pays income tax; in other words, everybody must pay additional tax. Whether it is $15, or $10, or $2, or $1, it is still taxation. If the Government obtains $1 by income tax, $5 by taxing cigarettes, $10 by taxing petrol, and so much by another kind of taxation, you will find that the poor worker will have to pay, not just $5 or $10, but much more than you think they do. Now it is said that

Column: 645

$2, $5 or $10 is a very small sum, but let me tell the Government this - the value of money today is not what it should be. If you compare the value of money in 1940 with what it is now, you will find, in all probability, that the value of money now is only one-fifth of what it was in 1940. I am putting this case not because you must spend more, but because I am going to talk about the taxpayer -[Interruption.]

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the hon. Member will address his remarks to the Chair, I think he will not be interrupted so frequently.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Yes, Sir. The barrage has started from the opposite Benches, Sir, and it is only right that they should receive a salvo in reply!

    Sir, I was talking about the poor income-tax payer. We tax on $3,000, but if you think about its value as compared to 1940 or so, it will roughly be $600 and that will work out to $50 a month, and $50 a month even in 1940, Sir, would not ensure a person a good standard of living.
